attributes.title: Voluntary Audits: Experimental Evidence on a Novel Approach to Bureaucratic Monitoring

q1.value: Voluntary Audits: Experimental Evidence on a Novel Approach to Bureaucratic Monitoring

q2.value: Ana De La O | Lucas González | Rebecca B. Weitz-Shapiro

q5.value: We thank Don Green, Rob Blair, Matt Winters, Kate Baldwin, Chappell Lawson, attendees at MIT Gov/Lab meetings, and attendees at EGAP’s meeting in Chile for useful feedback, as well as Catlan Reardon for excellent research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Is it possible to motivate bureaucrats to be honest and exert effort in their work without relying on punitive auditing systems? While state audit institutions are advocated as a solution to waste and corruption, especially in developing countries (Dye and Stapenhurst 1998), they have a mixed record of success. Traditional audits may fail to elicit greater bureaucratic effort (e.g., Litschig and Zamboni 2015) or may displace corruption as officials shift spending away from audited expenses (e.g., Olken 2007). Even where successful, they rely on the strength and autonomy of institutions like the media and judiciary (e.g., Ferraz and Finan 2008), which are often weak in many lower and middle income countries (Helmke and Rios-Figueroa 2011). Other interventions to improve bureaucratic performance employ financial and material incentives (e.g., Duflo, Hanna, and Ryan 2012), but these interventions rarely engage with existing oversight institutions and typically require an ongoing commitment of funds. We hypothesize that voluntary audits might be an effective tool for eliciting effort. Voluntary audits give street-level bureaucrats a choice and opportunity for self-direction, which existing scholarship suggests can increase intrinsic motivation (Ryan and Deci 2000). Separately, voluntary audits could provide bureaucrats with professional and social recognition, which scholars suggest matters for their performance (Pepinsky, Pierskalla, and Sacks 2017; Wilson 1989). If the opportunity to volunteer for an audit increases either intrinsic or extrinsic motivation, then we expect bureaucratic effort to increase and, potentially, outcomes to improve, as well. Our project aims to contribute to the small but growing literature that explores the role of non-financial incentives on pro-social activities and bureaucratic performance and recruitment (Ashraf, Bandiera, and Jack, 2014; Banuri and Keefer 2016; Dal Bó, Finan, and Rossi 2013). We partner with the Provincial Auditing Office (PAO) in Chaco, Argentina, to test whether a new system of voluntary audits improves the performance of school principals in their administration of a free meal program. Our field experiment intervenes in the oversight of a school meal program, in which principals are responsible for school-level implementation (including menu planning and overseeing food preparation). We randomly assign principals to receive an invitation to a voluntary audit or to be part of the control group, which is exposed to the status quo situation, where schools face a small (but non-zero) likelihood of a mandatory audit.

q16.value: We expect that principals in the treatment group will exert more effort in the implementation of the school meal program compared to the control group. To evaluate this hypothesis, we will measure the following outcomes collected directly from the endline survey of school principals: total number of hours worked, number of “extra” hours worked, and number of hours school principals report devoting to the meal program. We will also check whether any increase in hours comes at expense of time spent in other activities, as well as an index of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, and the extent to which principals consider the opinion of the provincial auditing office to be important to them. If the intervention changes school principals’ behavior and/or motivation, we expect the school meal program to improve. Our school-level outcomes include student attendance, which interviews with local experts suggest is linked to the number and quality of meals served, the proportion of days schools offer snack/lunch in a given reporting period, basic composition of the meals (for example, number of unique menus in a given reporting period, and number of meals that contain fresh fruits or vegetables), and number of days a school is closed, because unanticipated school closings may reflect lower principal effort to provide meals. Finally, we will explore if treatment interacts with baseline characteristics, including how embedded a school principal is in the school’s community, parental engagement in the school, and socio-economic composition of the school community. The study will allow us to describe the profile of school principals who accept a voluntary audit, and draw causal inferences on whether (1) voluntary audits generate a direct effect on school principals who receive an invitation to participate in a voluntary audit and, (2) whether the voluntary system generates spillover effects. Our sample includes 188 schools in 13 regions in the province of Chaco. To account for potential spillovers, we employ a two-level randomization. First, we assign the 13 regions to either a high density or low density treatment group. Second, within the high density group, we assign schools to treatment with a probability of 0.5; within the low density group, we assign schools to treatment with a probability of 0.16.

q17.value: Because randomization was blocked by region and probability of treatment varies by block, we will estimate the intent-to-treat effect by specifying a regression where the independent variables are a dummy variable measuring assignment to treatment and a set of dummy variables to account for region fixed effects. Observations will be weighted by the inverse of the probability of treatment. We will conduct two tailed hypotheses tests. To increase the precision of our statistical inferences, we will add baseline covariates to our specification. Following Annan, Boyer, Cooper, Heise, and Levy Paluck (2019), we will use an adaptive lasso to identify prognostic covariates to be included in our specification. We will present our results with and without baseline covariates. For the hypothesis about student attendance, since we will measure this outcome weekly in the period of June to October 2018, we will estimate the effects over time as specified in the pre-analysis plan. To detect spillovers, we will compare the means of schools assigned to control in regions with high density versus schools assigned to control in regions with low density. Then, we will specify a regression where the independent variables are: a dummy variable measuring assignment to treatment, a dummy variable measuring high versus low density regions, the interaction of the two previous dummies, as well as a set of dummy variables to account for region fixed effects. Observations will be weighted by the inverse of the probability of treatment.

q19.value: 188 schools in 13 regions in the province of Chaco, Argentina. This convenience sample includes preschool and primary schools in urban and semi-urban areas. Our sample size reflects the PAO’s capacity to conduct audits.

q24.value: Yale: IRB Protocol ID 2000021005; Brown: IRB Protocol ID 1704001741

attributes.title: Who Cares About Your Error Bar: A Survey Experiment on Visualizing Uncertainty in Political Science

q1.value: Who Cares About Your Error Bar: A Survey Experiment on Visualizing Uncertainty in Political Science

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: How can scholars convey uncertainty about empirical data? The general public frequently misinterprets data in journal articles, presentations, and the mass media, and especially struggles with uncertainty about estimated quantities. For example, even a highly educated figure like Chief Justice John Roberts recently referred to his difficulty understanding “social science gobbledygook”. Scholars and others seeking to communicate uncertainty about data usually turn to visual representations of margin of errors and data variability, since the general public has little understanding of statistical terminology. Research in statistics, graph theory, and psychology has found communicating point estimates and uncertainty to be challenging We conduct an experiment to determine what approaches to data visualization are most effective in communicating both point estimates and uncertainty to the general public. Our treatments test multiple formats: simple text, basic error bars, hypothetical outcome plots, and advanced error bars. Our results provide guidance on the best way to convey uncertainty to the public, and show how interpretation of uncertainty is undermined for partisan issues.

q16.value: • H1: The Hypothetical Outcome Plot, Gradient Plot, Regular Bar Chart with Error bars and a line of text will generate different levels of comprehension of the point estimates and uncertainty. • Null: The Hypothetical Outcome Plot, Gradient Plot, Regular Bar Chart with Error bats and a line of text will generate the same levels of comprehension of the point estimates and uncertainty. Sub Hypothesis: Those with a higher education level and with a background in math will have a better understanding of the uncertainty and will better understand the more difficult graphs like the Hypothetical Outcome Plot. Null: Those with a higher education level and with a background in math will have the same level of understanding of the uncertainty and will understand the more difficult graphs like the hypothetical outcome plot at a standard level.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested via a survey experiment using the online survey platform Qualtrics and an anonymous link will be posted to Facebook for the manipulation check of the survey, and using Amazon's mechanical turk for the main experiment. Potential respondents will view a brief description of the project on MTurk in order to decide whether to participate. In the manipulation check, participants were recruited via my personal social networks and social media platforms. All subjects were over the age of 18 and totaled 260 participants. The manipulation check consisted of a series of demographic questions asking about age, gender, partisanship and education background. The treatments consisted of a random assignment of one of four plots (hypothetical outcome plot, bar graph, a line of text, or a gradient plot). Respondents were asked to write a response interpreting the results shown in the graph. The results shown in the graph were results from a public opinion poll that contained information about two candidates in an upcoming election. In the main survey, I used registered users of Amazon's Mechanical Turk. The Mechanical Turk recruitment options are set to require the participants must be over the age of 18, and responding from IP addresses within the United States. I will use 400 participants per condition totaling 1,600 participants. Participants were compensated $0.60 for completing my survey. The rate is in accordance with the norms of Mechanical Turk that that amounts to $12/hour for my 5 minute survey task. After consenting to participate in my study on the opining page of the qualtrics survey, Mturk subjects were presented with a few questions about their demographics (age, gender, political affiliation and education). Respondents saw an attention check question that asks them to read a block of text and answer it with a spefic answer to see if they are reading carefully. If they got the question wrong, they see a warning message that says if they don't read carefully they may not be paid on Mturk. Next respondents will see a random pair out of four graphical representations (same as in the manipulation check) with a series of intro to statistics questions in order to test if respondents understand the uncertainty presented in the margin of errors of each graph.

attributes.title: Territorial Patterns, Administrative Capacity and Digital Development of Chilean Municipalities

q1.value: Territorial Patterns, Administrative Capacity and Digital Development of Chilean Municipalities

q5.value: This research has been possible thanks to the financial support of the Faculty of Economics and Administration of the Universidad de Santiago de Chile within the framework of the 2018 Academic Performance Agreement., I am grateful to Berenice Orvenes for her help with data collection and validation.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: There are several models for the evaluation of government Web portals. Fath-Allah et al. (2017; see also González-Bustamante et al., 2019) evaluate 25 recent models found in the academic literature. In line with the stages identified by Fath-Allah et al. (2017), Esteves (2005) elaborated a model of e-services grouped into five dimensions. This model has been adapted to study municipalities in Argentina, Chile, and Venezuela (see Bayona and Morales, 2017; Gómez, 2007; González-Bustamante et al., 2019). Moreover, the literature identifies a series of factors which determine the success of local e-government, among which are elements related with availability of technology infrastructure (see Alcaide-Muñoz et al., 2014; Lowatcharin and Menifield,2015), political factors, organisational factors or local administrative capacity (see Andrews and Entwistle, 2015; Andrews et al., 2013; Manoharan, 2013; Norris and Moon, 2005), and population characteristics. Esteves’ e-services model (2005; see also González-Bustamante et al., 2019) contains 15 items grouped into five dimensions to evaluate government Web portals (see Fath-Allah et al., 2017). Salazar et al. (2010) used this model for the Los Ríos Region of Chile, while González-Bustamante et al. (2019) carried out a measurement in 2016 in the five most populated regions in Chile: (i) Metropolitan (40.67% of the national population); (ii) Bío Bío (11.70%); (iii) Valparaíso (10.13%); (iv) La Araucanía (5,48%); and (v) Coquimbo (4,30%). This research applies the model for the 345 municipalities in all the regions in Chile. I carry out a binary measurement for each item and an aggregation based on Esteves (2005) formula, which allows for weightings theoretically associated to the level of digital sophistication and maturity of each phase.

q16.value: H_1. Administrative capacity (X_1) increases the probabilities of a municipality having a high E-Government Index (Y). H_2. Community capacity (X_2) increases the probabilities of a municipality having a high E-Government Index (Y). H_3. Social concentration (X_3) increases the probabilities of a municipality having a high E-Government Index (Y). H_4. Population size (X_4) increases the probabilities of a municipality having a high E-Government Index (Y). H_5. Population complexity (X_5) decreases the probabilities of a municipality having a high E-Government Index (Y).

q17.value: The research design is based on the use of different statistical techniques. Firstly, I calculate, describe, and georeference the E-Government Index (EGi). Secondly, I calculate spatial autocorrelation indicators. Finally, I analyse the predictors associated with a high index using spatial econometric models. I use the Moran index (Moran-I), analogous to the Pearson coefficient for spatial units (Goodchild, 2008), in two variants: under the assumption of randomisation and with a Monte Carlo simulation. On one hand, Moran-I under randomisation involves a random permutation of spatial units to obtain spatial autocorrelation and statistical significance values (Celemín, 2009). On the other hand, The Markov Chain Monte Carlo simulation (MCMC) enables me to know random variables of a sample based on their probability distribution (Jackman, 2004). I carry out 10,000 simulations for each analysis. These Bayesian simulations allow learn about the posterior density by sampling iteration (Jackman, 2004). Specifically, I use the Gibbs sampler, a special case of the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm (Trumbo and Suess, 2014). I have programmed a code in R to elaborate spatial contiguity neighbours’ matrixes with vector data from Territorial Information System of the National Congress Library of Chile (SIIT-BCN in Spanish) in order to calculate Moran-I under randomisation and with MCMC. I work with matrixes of all regions based on the Sphere of Influence (SOI) model, a matrix derived from the Delaunay triangulation of neighbours, where the relation between points is based on Euclidean distance. In the SOI matrixes, triangulation is reduced by removing links that are relatively distant (Bivand et al., 2013). First, I fit three Ordinary Least Squares models (OLS), each one with different control variables. These models allow evaluate the spatial autocorrelation in the residuals with Moran-I. If the test is statistically significant at 95%, the residuals are spatially clustered, hence it is necessary to fit spatial econometric models. Subsequently, I fit three SAR models and three SEM models, each one with different statistical controls also and with the likelihood function.

attributes.title: The Marriage Effect: Influence of Marital Status on Perceptions of Female Candidates in India

q1.value: The Marriage Effect: Influence of Marital Status on Perceptions of Female Candidates in India

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Countries around the world have seen an increase in women's participation in politics, though expectations have far exceeded the reality. Outside of offices with gender quotas, women's candidacy and election into office still lags far behind that of men's-especially in countries that hold highly patriarchal views. In India, for instance, women make up over 33 percent to 50 percent of village-level offices, or gram panchayats, due to gender quotas. Yet, the proportion of female candidates running for higher-levels of federal offices have merely increased from 2.7 percent in 1962 to 7.4 percent in 2014 (Jensenius 2018). In 2014, women only made up 11 percent of the elected Lower House of Parliament or Lok Sabha members (ibid). Though the data suggests that women get elected at higher levels than men upon running for office, Jensenius (2018) finds that the credit ought to go to parties, not voters, who field women in uncompetitive constituencies to win 'soft' seats. Despite these trends, India has had several prominent national- and state-level female leaders, including Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, but the electoral field has largely remained male-dominated. This slow pace of growth in India is puzzling alongside two trends in electoral politics. One, the advent of gender quotas in the 1990s have improved perceptions of women as leaders, at least at the local level (Beaman et al. 2009). We would therefore expect improved perceptions of women to coincide with a greater likelihood of women running for and winning political office. Two, the National Election Studies found that the gender gap in voting has all but closed as approximately 66 percent of both men and women participated in elections in 2014. If women's perceptions as leaders are improving and women are increasingly becoming a key part of the electoral process, why are we failing to see more women in politics? To answer the question, I specifically examine how women's role in society impact voters' perception of them as candidates. Specifically, I use a survey experiment to examine whether the prototype of the Indian woman as a housewife, mother, and daughter constricts how voters perceive women who run. I do so by varying two variables: (1) a fictitious female candidate's marital status (married, unmarried, widowed) and (2) whether or not they are a dynastic politician.

q16.value: To examine the question, I will implement an online survey experiment on Qualtrics, which will be advertised on Facebook in India to recruit respondents. The survey experiment will manipulate two categories in a fictitious profile of a female candidate running for office: her marital status and her family background. Marital status categories will be unmarried, married, or widowed. Family background categories will be that her family has a background in politics and her family has no background in politics. Together, these two fields are eliciting implicit assumptions respondents make about a candidate profile, and then explicitly informing them about dynastic politics involvement to gauge whether feelings about the candidate change. The hypotheses are listed below: Main effects: H1: Widowed women are viewed as more competent than married and unmarried women, keeping age constant. H2: Voters will state a preference for voting in favor of widowed women over married women and married women over unmarried women, holding age constant. H3: H1-H2 will not change, even if voters state no explicit gender bias in their own attitudes. H4: Explicitly informing voters that a woman’s family background is not in politics will reduce their perception of her competence, but increase their preference for voting for her. Heterogenous effects: I will conduct a subgroup analysis for heterogenous effects for the following variables, but I do not expect to see differences across the groups as I believe the treatment illicits a subconscious response: gender of the respondent, BJP supporter versus non-BJP supporter, and education level (12th grade and below or higher education).

q17.value: I will conduct the survey experiment on Qualtrics, for which respondents will be recruited through a Facebook ad to win a smartphone through a drawing. I opt for Facebook given that this sample will be more targeted than one recruited by Mechanical Turk in India. Using a sample size of approximately 1800 (200 per treatment arm), I will recruit individuals from across the country, with targeted ads in smaller, tier-1 cities, and amongst women to ensure gender balance in the respondents. Given that the survey is online and in English, I do not claim any representativeness of the survey. Instead, it merely seeks to disentangle the effect of marital status on voters' perceptions and the underlying mechanisms. If the method described above on Facebook yields low response rates, I will use mTurk to collect the data.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Countries around the world have seen an increase in women's participation in politics, though expectations have far exceeded the reality. Outside of offices with gender quotas, women's candidacy and election into office still lags far behind that of men's-especially in countries that hold highly patriarchal views. In India, for instance, women make up over 33 percent to 50 percent of village-level offices, or gram panchayats, due to gender quotas. Yet, the proportion of female candidates running for higher-levels of federal offices have merely increased from 2.7 percent in 1962 to 7.4 percent in 2014 (Jensenius 2018). In 2014, women only made up 11 percent of the elected Lower House of Parliament or Lok Sabha members (ibid). Though the data suggests that women get elected at higher levels than men upon running for office, Jensenius (2018) finds that the credit ought to go to parties, not voters, who field women in uncompetitive constituencies to win 'soft' seats. Despite these trends, India has had several prominent national- and state-level female leaders, including Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, but the electoral field has largely remained male-dominated. This slow pace of growth in India is puzzling alongside two trends in electoral politics. One, the advent of gender quotas in the 1990s have improved perceptions of women as leaders, at least at the local level (Beaman et al. 2009). We would therefore expect improved perceptions of women to coincide with a greater likelihood of women running for and winning political office. Two, the National Election Studies found that the gender gap in voting has all but closed as approximately 66 percent of both men and women participated in elections in 2014. If women's perceptions as leaders are improving and women are increasingly becoming a key part of the electoral process, why are we failing to see more women in politics? To answer the question, I specifically examine how women's role in society impact voters' perception of them as candidates. Specifically, I use a survey experiment to examine whether the prototype of the Indian woman as a housewife, mother, and daughter constricts how voters perceive women who run. I do so by varying two variables: (1) a fictitious female candidate's marital status (married, unmarried, widowed) and (2) whether or not they are a dynastic politician.

Marital status categories will be unmarried, married, or widowed. Family background categories will be that her family has a background in politics and her family has no background in politics. Together, these two fields are eliciting implicit assumptions respondents make about a candidate profile, and then explicitly informing them about dynastic politics involvement to gauge whether feelings about the candidate change. The hypotheses are listed below: Main effects: H1: Widowed women are viewed as more competent than married and unmarried women, keeping age constant. H2: Voters will state a preference for voting in favor of widowed women over married women and married women over unmarried women, holding age constant. H3: H1-H2 will not change, even if voters state no explicit gender bias in their own attitudes. H4: Explicitly informing voters that a woman’s family background is not in politics will reduce their perception of her competence, but increase their preference for voting for her. q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The starting point of many studies on gender and politics has been that men are overrepresented in politics, whereas women constitute only a small minority of elected officials. In this project, this underrepresentation of women in politics serves as the main starting point. More in particular, the role of political gender stereotypes as a source of voter bias is explored. Previous research on political gender stereotypes was mostly set in the context of the United States, where female representatives are rather scarce and concentrated within the Democratic Party. Generally, women were considered as competent in communal areas, such as education and health care, whereas male candidates excel in all other issue domains. Women are also perceived as more leftist than men. However, we cannot simply extrapolate the results of these American studies to other political systems, since the US has a distinct political culture and context. The European context, and List PR-systems in particular, has not been investigated in these matters. In this project, the focus is on Flanders (Belgium). The combination of a highly proportional List-PR system and a stringent quota system results in higher shares of elected women (one of the highest in the world), a very fragmented party system with female politicians relatively equally spread over the different parties, and less focus on individual candidates. These consequences of using a List-PR provide a political context that is more woman-friendly compared to majoritarian systems. Hence, this presents an interesting case to conduct research on the prevalence of political gender stereotypes.

q16.value: Our aim is to find out whether gender stereotypes are present in the Flemish political sphere. Our expectation is that general gender stereotypes will be reflected in politics in two ways: perceptions that female and male politicians have different issue competences and hold different ideological positions. Regarding the different areas of issue expertise, we expect that women, because they are typically seen as communal and social, will be stereotyped as having more competence in communal issues. Conversely, we expect that women will be perceived as being less competent in agentic issues. For neutral issues, we do not expect differences. This leads us to the following hypotheses: H1a: The perceived general competences of women candidates on agentic issues will be lower than that of men candidates. H1b: The perceived general competences of women candidates on neutral issues will be similar than that of men candidates. H1c: The perceived general competences of women candidates on communal issues will be higher than that of men candidates. Another component of political gender stereotypes is the different perception of the social attitudes and political beliefs of women (Diekman et al., 2002). Although women are more equally spread over the different parties in Flanders, we believe that also there female candidates will be perceived as being more leftist, since they are also seen as possessing communal traits, as more competent to handle communal issues and to write more legislation on women’s issues (Welch & Thomas, 1991). H2: The perceived ideological position of women candidates will be more to the left than that of men candidates. Also list position cues are very important in the Flemish List-PR system. Following interaction theory (Peffley, Hurwitz, & Sniderman, 1997), both gender and list position cues potentially work in tandem to help voters to form coherent impressions (Kundra & Sinclair, 1999). We therefore also want to investigate whether women benefit from a head of list position. From a gender perspective, one could argue that a female candidate may benefit from a head of list position, because the information attached to this high list position (i.e. candidates listed first are highly competent) is deviant from the general impression of female candidates. Moreover, despite stringent quota regulations, the number of female head of list candidates is below that of male head of list candidates. Therefore, voters might have the impression that those female candidates who succeed in obtaining a top list position have to be extremely qualified. H3a: The perceived general competence of female head of list candidates will be higher than that of male head of list candidates. On the other hand, it is plausible to argue that female candidates with a middle of list position will be worse off. Quota regulations are often criticized for leading to the selection of unqualified candidates just to meet the quota standards (see for example Júlio & Tavares, 2017; Wauters, Maddens, & Put, 2014; Weeks & Baldez, 2015), which possibly result in lower levels of perceived competence for female middle of list candidates. H3b: The perceived general competence of female middle of list candidates will be lower than that of male middle of list candidates.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested on the basis of an experimental research design in which hypothetical candidates were presented to respondents in text messages in which only their sex, their position on the list and their policy position on a particular issue were mentioned. We did not mention the party affiliation of the presented candidates and the policy statements all took a centrist position, in order not to influence the assessment of the ideological position of the presented candidates. Our study used a 2x3x6 mixed complete block design. The candidate’s sex (male versus female) and the list position (head of list, position in the middle or no list position mentioned) were manipulated as between-group factors. Six different policy issues were manipulated as within-groups factor. We included two topics that are generally perceived as being communal (health care and education), two agentic topics (defence and finance) and two gender-neutral topics (tourism and climate). This categorization is based on an extensive review of 16 international studies on the assignment of policy issues to men and women by three key actors, i.e. (mass) media, voters and party elites . We also checked whether these findings hold in our Flemish context by exploring literature on portfolio allocations and by looking at the appointment of male and female ministers to these issue domains. Respondents were randomly assigned to six different treatments. After each text message, respondents were asked to complete a questionnaire about the presented candidate and message, before continuing to the next profile. The order of the issue domains was randomized in order to control for order effects. There was also a random variation of male and female candidates, and of head of list and middle of list candidates. The hypothetical candidates were presented as ‘candidate X’. In Dutch, it is possible to indicate the different sex of these candidates (‘kandidaat’ for the male candidate and ‘kandidate’ for the female candidate). Likewise gender-linked pronouns were used in the instructional paragraphs and questions. In all other respects, speeches and questionnaires were identical, in order not to provide any cues to the salience of gender. The presented stimuli included several elements: a text message, an image of the ballot (where we indicated the list position of the candidate) and a facial silhouette of the hypothetical candidate. The inclusion of facial silhouettes is innovative and is a subtle cue to respondents about the sex of the candidate. Previous studies mostly indicated the sex of the presented candidate by presenting him/her with a clear male/female name (e.g. Dolan, 2014; Huddy & Terkildsen, 1993b; Matland, 1994; Rosenwasser et al., 1987), or by including images (see for example Aalberg & Jenssen, 2007; Lammers et al., 2009). However, psychical appearance also impacts on the perception of the presented candidates (Lammers et al., 2009). Furthermore, also names can evoke certain prejudices because they possibly remind respondents of someone with the same name or because they simply (dis)like the name. The text messages were made as centrist as possible, and were based on a mix of the party programs of the four Flemish centre parties (CD&V, Open VLD, N-VA and sp.a), the Flemish government agreement and Flemish parties’ press statements. Manipulation checks were included to verify whether respondents were able to correctly answer questions about the candidate and the content of the message. All respondents had to answer a question about the sex of the presented candidate after the first treatment. Respondents who were not able to correctly answer this question could not further complete the questionnaire and their answers were not taken into account for the data analysis. We also included other manipulation checks, in order not to over-accentuate the importance of the candidate’s sex. Furthermore, respondents were incentivized to read the text messages thoroughly by highlighting that a prize (iPad Air 2 128 GB) would be raffled among those who could answer all the substantive questions correctly. The most important advantage of an experimental approach is the possibility to control for a number of intervening factors. Several measures were taken to ensure that only our key variable (i.e. the sex of the candidate) plays a role in the evaluation made by the respondents. First, the institutional context was held constant by focusing on Flanders. Second, the characteristics of respondents were controlled by randomly assigning them to one of the different treatments and by making comparisons between experimental groups. Third, by using hypothetical candidates without partisan affiliation, we did not intervene in actual discussion nor was there any effect of pre-existing preferences or personal (dis)tastes. Taken together, all these measures offer a methodologically rigid test. The experiment was conducted in March-April 2017. Respondents were drawn from iVOX’s internet-based access panel, which is the largest online panel in Flanders with about 150,000 potential respondents. 11,837 of them actually received an invitation to participate in our study and 4,052 agreed to participate. After discarding respondents who could not correctly answer the question about the sex of the first presented candidate (see above), we retained 2,500 participants. From this sample, we additionally excluded two categories of respondents. First, respondents who completed the survey too fast, and consequently gave random answers, were excluded. These so-called ‘speeder respondents’ were defined as those who completed the survey in less than half of the average completion time. Second, a question about the possible purpose of this study was included at the end of the survey. Twenty-seven respondents provided an answer that was in line with the purpose of our research. We decided to exclude the answers of those respondents as there might be a social desirability bias in these answers. However, since we also asked them to indicate at what point they found this out (while completing the questions for the first, second,…, sixth candidate), we did not have to exclude all of their answers. The exact number of registered answers varies therefore by policy issue. After excluding these two types of respondents, we maintained a sample of 2,362 respondents (which is a response rate of 19.95 %). The external validity of our experiment is enhanced by conducting the study among a sample of the population, whereas most other studies analyse university students. This increases the generalizability of our results.

attributes.title: Down-Ballot Decision Making: Voter Information Acquisition, Processing, & Heuristics

q1.value: Down-Ballot Decision Making: Voter Information Acquisition, Processing, & Heuristics

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: What factors affect the process through which voters seek information when making decisions among contesting candidates for different offices at different levels of government? When do voters choose to acquire information, and when do they rely on heuristics? This paper details a novel survey experiment designed to measure voter demand for, and the influence of, different types of information on voters’ candidate choices across electoral contests and levels of government.

q16.value: See attached paper for specific hypotheses, as well as theoretical reasoning. General hypotheses include (1) voter cognitive processing strategies will be different across federal electoral levels, (2) voters in local elections will be more likely to search for information than voters in non-local elections, and (3 a & b) voters in local elections will be more likely ( or less likely) to use heuristics than voters in non-local elections.

q17.value: Data will be collected through respondents on MTurk. See attached paper for details on the experimental design, treatment conditions, and measures to be collected.

attributes.title: Institutional Legacies, Identity and Collective Action in Rural Mexico

q1.value: Institutional Legacies, Identity and Collective Action in Rural Mexico

q5.value: Funding for this project comes from the Graduate Student Research Grant in International Development at the Stanford Center for International Development (SCID) and from the Freeman Spogli Institue research grant. Additional travel expenses were covered b

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This study seeks to identify the legacies of institutional history at local level on different dimensions of collective action and identity. Using a survey instrument in rural Mexico -with an embedded experimental design, I compare two types of localities with different institutional backgrounds: towns with a colonial origin and autonomy legacy, and towns formed around haciendas. By conducting a deeper exploration of individual level outcomes, this study advances our understanding of the developmental challenges inflicted by long-term institutional legacies. I hypothesize that towns with a historic legacy of autonomy are more likely to solve collective action dilemmas than hacienda-originated towns. The questionnaire intends to identify some routes of collective action and the mechanisms behind institutional reinforcement.

q16.value: The main hypotheses to be tested are: Localities that were Indian Republics have higher coordination capacity than former haciendas. Localities that were Indian Republics also present harsher punishment for defection and rule breaking. Finally, a set of hypotheses on regional identity will be tested: Places with higher levels of autonomy present stronger regional autonomy.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested by comparing outcomes from a survey instrument on a sample of former Indian republics and a sample of former haciendas. To address endogeneity concerns, the survey includes an embedded experiment.

attributes.title: Do Electorally-Vulnerable Legislators Grant More or Less Statutory Discretion?

q1.value: Do Electorally-Vulnerable Legislators Grant More or Less Statutory Discretion?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: What is the effect of electoral competition on statutory discretion? The literature on legislative productivity and bureaucratic delegation collectively suggest that legislators engage in the statutory discretion in legislation to pursue credit claiming opportunities and minimize bureaucratic oversight. If legislators are single-minded seekers of reelection, it is necessary to determine the effect of individual electoral competition on statutory discretion. I argue that an increase in a legislator’s electoral competition results in an increase in statutory discretion. I utilize a within-subject natural experiment in California to test the effect of a change in a California State Senate district’s party registration and president’s vote share on the State Senator’s statutory discretion in introductory legislation before and after the California Citizens Redistricting Commission’s inaugural release of the California Senate district maps in 2011 and 2012. Once a legislator is subject to an electorally-competitive legislative district, I expect a legislator grants more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy.

q16.value: The dependent variable is the degree of statutory discretion the legislator grants to the bureaucracy in her/his introduced legislation. I measure statutory discretion as (1) the number of added minus repealed words, and (2) the number of legislative intent words in each introduced bill. The independent variables are a legislator’s electoral competition in her/his current and future districts. For each district, I measure electoral competition as (1) the change in legislator’s party registration/president’s vote share before and after the maps are released, and (2) the change in the legislator’s party registration/president’s vote share advantage over the other major political party before and after the maps are released. H1 (Lame duck): If a legislator is not running for election or reelection to any elected office, the legislator will grant less statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. H2 (Higher office): If a legislator is running for election to higher office, the legislator will grant less statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. H3 (Electoral competition): If a legislator is subject to an increase in electoral competition, the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. H4 (Electoral competition – future district): If a legislator is subject to an increase in electoral competition in their future district (i.e., the district he/she will run in the next election), the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. H5 (Election year): If a legislator running for election or reelection to elected office in an election year, the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy.

q17.value: I intend to use (1) a paired and unpaired difference-in-means t-test and (2) regression analysis (with individual member fixed effects) to separately test each hypothesis. I specify the t-tests and fixed-effects regressions for each hypothesis below. I will use regression analysis (with individual member control variables) to simultaneously test all of the hypotheses. H1 (Lame duck): If a legislator is not running for election or reelection to any elected office, the legislator will grant less statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. Empirical test: Paired difference-in-means t-test for the subgroup to determine effect of last year in elected office as a lame duck legislator; unpaired difference-in-means t-tests to compare lame duck legislators in their last term or last year to legislators running for reelection or election. H2 (Higher office): If a legislator is running for election to higher office, the legislator will grant less statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. Empirical test: Unpaired difference-in-means t-test to compare legislators running for reelection or election to the same type of elected office compared to legislators running for reelection or election to higher office; paired and unpaired difference-in-means t-test to test interaction effect by election year (i.e., whether running for a higher office in 2012 or not.) H3 (Electoral competition): If a legislator is subject to an increase in electoral competition, the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. Empirical test: Paired difference-in-means t-test by categorical measure of electoral competition in current and future legislative districts; regression analysis with categorical/continuous measure of electoral competition in current and future legislative districts with individual member fixed effects. H4 (Electoral competition – future district): If a legislator is subject to an increase in electoral competition in their future district (i.e., the district he/she will run in the next election), the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. Empirical test: (Same empirical test as H3, but focus on future district variables to determine legislators’ past or future-oriented behavior.) Paired difference-in-means t-test by categorical measure of electoral competition in current and future legislative districts; regression analysis with categorical/continuous measure of electoral competition in current and future legislative districts with individual member fixed effects; paired and unpaired difference-in-means t-test to test interaction effect by election year (i.e., whether running for a higher office in 2012 or not.) H5 (Election year): If a legislator running for election or reelection to elected office in an election year, the legislator will grant more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy. Empirical test: Unpaired difference-in-means t-test to compare legislators running for reelection or election in an election year (2012) to legislators running for reelection or election not in an election year.

q19.value: Approximately 40 California State Senators; 1600 introduced bills

q27.value: Since this is a natural experiment, the "intervention" was carried out by the California Citizens Redistricting Commission's release of the 2012 State Senate district maps in spring/summer 2011.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: What is the effect of electoral competition on statutory discretion? The literature on legislative productivity and bureaucratic delegation collectively suggest that legislators engage in the statutory discretion in legislation to pursue credit claiming opportunities and minimize bureaucratic oversight. If legislators are single-minded seekers of reelection, it is necessary to determine the effect of individual electoral competition on statutory discretion. I argue that an increase in a legislator’s electoral competition results in an increase in statutory discretion. I utilize a within-subject natural experiment in California to test the effect of a change in a California State Senate district’s party registration and president’s vote share on the State Senator’s statutory discretion in introductory legislation before and after the California Citizens Redistricting Commission’s inaugural release of the California Senate district maps in 2011 and 2012. Once a legislator is subject to an electorally-competitive legislative district, I expect a legislator grants more statutory discretion to the bureaucracy.

attributes.title: The normalization of authoritarian symbols: evidence from the process of Catalan independence

q1.value: The normalization of authoritarian symbols: evidence from the process of Catalan independence

q2.value: Elias Dinas | Vicente Valentim | Sergi Martínez

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In Spain, public expressions of nationalism were sanctioned because they were associated with the dictatorial past that the country experienced. The observational section of the paper, however, shows that the number of flags displayed in the façade of buildings increased as a consequence of the process of Catalan independence. To dig deeper into the mechanism behind this effect, we employ a survey to look at differences in respondents living in streets with and without Spanish flags on their balconies; and in differences in respondents that live in streets with many and with few Spanish flags on their façades.

q16.value: Thus, we aim to estimate the effect of living in streets with flags’ displaced on the façades on the social desirability to express opinions towards an authoritarian past. We would expect individuals displaying flags in their balconies and individuals living in areas with many flags to not differ much in their true attitudes towards the authoritarian past. Rather, they should differ in their willingness to display those preferences.

q17.value: A test of this hypothesis requires some measure of individuals’ true preferences, measured in a way that is as free from social desirtablity as possible. That is why we rely on a list experiment, which is particularly well suited to deal with sensitive questions, regarding which there is strong social desirability bias (Kuklinski, Cobb, and Gilens 1997). By making respondents report how many—but not which statements they agree with, these experiments make it more likely that respondents will display their true preferences.

q27.value: Intercampo, a survey company. Link: https://www.intercampo.es/somos.php)

attributes.title: Team and Nation? How Sports Games Affect National and Pan-African Identification in Kenya and Tanzania

q1.value: Team and Nation? How Sports Games Affect National and Pan-African Identification in Kenya and Tanzania

q5.value: We are grateful to Alex Coppock, Rafaela Dancygier, Francis Fukuyama, Evan Lieberman, Salma Mousa, Lisa Mueller, Ken Opalo, Paluck lab, Dan Posner, Maya Tudor, and Carlos Velasco for providing helpful comments on our research design and survey., We thank MIT GOV/LAB and the Princeton Bobst Center for research funding. This project is approved under Princeton IRB 11821 and MIT COUHES E-1392.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: How do major national events, such as a national sports team's win, affect citizens' national identification and attitudes and behaviors towards out-groups, foreign and domestic? Recent research reveals that national sports team victories lead to greater national identification and increased trust between ethnic groups. While an enhanced affinity for the nation may be a beneficial way to reduce out-group animosity, it is likely limited to nationally-bounded out-groups. It is an open question what type of nationalism (inclusive or exclusionary) is activated and how this increased identification might influence attitudes towards non-nationals. We test this idea with a natural experiment coupled with a survey experiment conducted using an online panel around the 2019 Africa Cup football (soccer) team match between two neighbors and rivals in East Africa, Kenya and Tanzania. We examine how a national sports victory changes types of identification (national, pan-African, East African, ethnic) and how this affects attitudes toward different out-groups that extend beyond national borders including, citizens from the country of the rival team, immigrants, and refugees. We similarly analyze the effects of a national sports team loss on these same outcomes.

q16.value: First, we seek to replicate previous research that national sports wins increase citizens' national identification. Similarly, we will examine the effect of a loss. Second, we will empirically test the idea that increased national identification improves co-national non-coethnic cooperation and trust, but may strain relations with non-nationals, particularly citizens from neighboring countries and refugees. Third, this project will go deeper into investigating exactly what type of nationalism is primed by shared experiences of national sports games and the mechanism through which national identification increases post a national sports team win. We will use the typology of identification proposed by Robinson, 2016. We will measure levels of all three proposed types of nationalism (affective, behavioral, and cognitive). We also want to examine which of these types of nationalism is most strongly connected to more positive attitudes towards non-nationals. Fourth, we will examine the effects of participating in a continent-wide competition on supranational identities, namely a pan-African identity. The recent literature on identity politics in Africa largely ignores this aspect of identity. We believe it is possible through this type of experience, for citizens to both identify with their nation and feel greater pride in their African identity, and that these are not mutually exclusive. By including a pan-African survey experimental prime that aims to increase pan-African identification, we want to know if this will also increase respondents' feelings of inclusion towards non-nationals, countering the exclusionary effects of nationalism.

q17.value: We take advantage of a natural experiment of the timing and outcome of the 2019 Africa Cup of Nations, a biennial international men's football championship organized by the Confederation of African Football (CAF). The main treatment is the natural experiment outcome of the June 27 match between Kenya and Tanzania. We will conduct a panel survey with a 30 day window (15 days before the match for the baseline, and 15 days after for the endline). The two teams are similarly matched, so the expectations for the match outcome are not obvious. We will also include two survey experimental treatments that attempt to frame the match in ways that promote inclusion, specifically inclusion of other conationals (Diversity Prime), and inclusion of non-nationals (Pan-African Prime). We will recruit survey respondents from both countries through Facebook ads, directing them to take the baseline survey online on Qualtrics. Facebook users in Kenya and Tanzania who are 18 years or older will be targeted with ads offering airtime credit for their participation in an academic survey. In the baseline survey, we will collect respondents' mobile phone numbers and use Telerivet, an SMS and voice platform to send them their first participation token, and a randomly generated date within the endline period to take the endline survey. On that date, we will send them a link to the endline survey through a Telerivet SMS. They have 24 hours to complete this survey, and upon completion, we will send them their second participation token.
